name: Reviews, Retros & Reflection Evaluator
description: Evaluates retrospectives for psychological safety, data-driven insights, actionable outcomes, and continuous improvement focus

scale.1: Blame culture evident (finger pointing, defensiveness, personal attacks)
scale.2: Some blame language, people-focused criticism, not fully safe to speak
scale.3: Mostly blameless, some slips into people-focus, Prime Directive mentioned but not enforced
scale.4: Consistently blameless, systems-focused, Prime Directive established, encourages honest feedback
scale.5: Exemplary: Prime Directive explicitly stated and reinforced, completely blameless language, focuses on systems/processes not people, psychological safety actively built (confidentiality, no judgment), dissenting opinions encouraged and valued

scale.1: Vague recollections only ('things were bad'), no concrete data or examples
scale.2: Some anecdotes but mostly opinions, missing metrics or specific events
scale.3: Mix of data (metrics, events) and sentiment, basic coverage of period
scale.4: Comprehensive data: metrics (velocity, bugs, incidents), events (launches, decisions), sentiment (team energy), specific examples
scale.5: Exemplary: Rich data from multiple sources (metrics dashboard, timeline of events, team surveys, customer feedback), balanced quantitative and qualitative, patterns identified across data, surprises and wins highlighted

criteria.name: Insight Generation and Root Cause Analysis

scale.1: No insights, just list of complaints or surface observations
scale.2: Basic observations but no depth, symptoms identified but not root causes
scale.3: Some root cause analysis (one level of 'why'), patterns noted, themes identified
scale.4: Deep root cause analysis (5 Whys, fishbone, timeline analysis), clear themes with supporting evidence, distinguishes symptoms from causes
scale.5: Exemplary: Rigorous root cause techniques applied, patterns across multiple retros identified, systemic issues surfaced (not just immediate causes), surprising insights discovered, connections made between seemingly unrelated items, both process and cultural factors explored

scale.1: Vague actions ('improve communication', 'do better'), no specificity or ownership
scale.2: Actions stated but missing SMART elements (no owner, deadline, or measurability)
scale.3: Actions are mostly SMART but some elements weak (vague success criteria, unrealistic scope)
scale.4: All actions are SMART (Specific, Measurable, Assigned, Realistic, Time-bound), clear and achievable
scale.5: Exemplary: Actions exceed SMART criteria (addresses root causes not symptoms, team has authority to implement, concrete first steps defined, success criteria binary or numeric, owners present and committed, 1-3 high-impact actions not overwhelming list)

scale.1: One or two voices dominate, most team silent or absent
scale.2: Unbalanced participation, some voices not heard, no facilitation to balance
scale.3: Most participate but some imbalance, facilitator makes some effort to include all
scale.4: Balanced participation, facilitator actively ensures all voices heard, techniques used (silent brainstorming, round-robin)
scale.5: Exemplary: All voices heard and valued, silent/async methods used to balance introverts/extroverts, dominant voices managed tactfully, psychological safety enables honest participation from all, diverse perspectives explicitly sought

scale.1: No review of previous actions, no tracking, actions forgotten after retro
scale.2: Previous actions mentioned but not tracked, no completion metrics, unclear accountability
scale.3: Previous actions reviewed with some status updates, basic tracking, completion rate noted
scale.4: Previous actions systematically reviewed (done/in-progress/blocked), completion rate calculated (target >80%), owners accountable, follow-up scheduled
scale.5: Exemplary: Action completion tracked across retros (dashboard or log), completion rate >80% achieved, incomplete actions discussed (why? pivot or continue?), follow-up meeting scheduled, retro actions linked to work tracking system, team celebrates completed actions, retro-to-retro learning visible

scale.1: Format clearly mismatched (Timeline for 1-week sprint, or no structure at all)
scale.2: Generic format used without considering context (always same format regardless of need)
scale.3: Format somewhat appropriate but could be better matched to situation
scale.4: Format well-matched to context (period length, team needs, goals)
scale.5: Exemplary: Format deliberately chosen with rationale (Start/Stop/Continue for action focus, Mad/Sad/Glad for morale, 4Ls for depth, Timeline for complex period), adapted to team preferences and needs, variety across retros to prevent staleness

scale.1: Retro feels like venting session with no improvement focus, no actions or same actions every time
scale.2: Some improvement intent but actions vague or not followed through, same issues recurring
scale.3: Clear improvement focus, some progress on issues, a few recurring themes addressed
scale.4: Strong improvement culture, actions tracked and completed, progress visible over time, recurring issues escalated
scale.5: Exemplary: Measurable improvement over time (metrics, team health, action completion >80%), retro process itself improves (ROTI scores, format experiments), learning documented and shared, recurring issues systematically addressed or escalated, celebration of progress and wins, team proactively requests retros

sprint_retro.key_focus: Process improvements, team dynamics, technical practices

project_postmortem.key_focus: Systemic learnings, documentation updates, playbook changes
project_postmortem.action_targets: Update documentation, refine playbooks, address skill gaps

weekly_review.key_focus: Celebrate wins, remove blockers, align on priorities

incident_retro.action_targets: Incident response process, monitoring/alerting, prevention measures
red_flags: Stopped at symptom (didn't reach root cause)

too_many_actions.root_cause: Want to fix everything, don't prioritize, unrealistic about capacity
too_many_actions.fix: Dot vote for top 1-3 high-impact actions, defer others to future retros, track completion rate and adjust

vague_actions.symptom: Actions like 'improve communication', 'do better testing' without specifics
vague_actions.root_cause: Didn't apply SMART criteria, rushed action planning, facilitator didn't push for specificity
vague_actions.fix: Use SMART template explicitly, facilitator role-plays action completion to test specificity ('how exactly would you do this?')

blame_culture.symptom: Finger pointing, defensiveness, people stop speaking honestly, same safe topics every retro
blame_culture.root_cause: Prime Directive not established, people-focused language, leadership doesn't model blamelessness
blame_culture.fix: State Prime Directive explicitly every retro, shift language from 'you' to 'the system', facilitator redirects blame to process, leadership training on blameless culture

no_follow_up.symptom: Actions from previous retro ignored, <50% completion, trust erodes, retros feel like theater
no_follow_up.root_cause: No tracking system, no accountability, actions not integrated into work flow, too ambitious actions
no_follow_up.fix: Create action tracking dashboard (visible to team), review at start of every retro, integrate actions into sprint/work planning, reduce action count to achievable 1-3

same_issues_recurring.symptom: Same problem appears >3 retros with no progress
same_issues_recurring.root_cause: Team lacks authority to fix (systemic issue beyond team), actions don't address root cause, leadership not engaged
same_issues_recurring.fix: Escalate to leadership with data ('issue X mentioned in last 4 retros, team can't solve alone'), use root cause analysis to go deeper, request organizational support or decision

low_participation.symptom: <70% attendance, few people contribute, dominated by 1-2 voices
low_participation.root_cause: Retro not valued (no action follow-through), not psychologically safe, format is stale, poor facilitation
low_participation.fix: Improve action follow-through (builds trust), rotate facilitator, experiment with formats, use silent/async techniques to include all, one-on-ones to understand barriers

excellence_indicators: Prime Directive stated explicitly and enforced throughout
Blameless language consistently used (systems-focused, not people-focused)
Comprehensive data gathered: metrics + events + sentiment
Root cause analysis conducted (5 Whys, fishbone, timeline)
Patterns and themes identified across observations
Actions address root causes, not just symptoms
Previous actions reviewed with >80% completion rate
Follow-up meeting scheduled for action tracking
Format appropriate to context and team needs
Continuous improvement focus evident (measurable progress over time)
ROTI score >80% thumbs up (retro itself is valuable)
Learning documented and shared beyond team when relevant
